title: How to Get a Stain out of a Microfiber Couch

steps.headline: Pour a small amount of rubbing alcohol on a white towel.
Rub the stain gently with the towel.
steps.description: Be sure to contain the alcohol to only the stained portion of the couch.

steps.headline: Wipe it clean of any excess alcohol.
Repeat 2 to 3 times until the stain is removed.
steps.description: This method also works to remove water rings, lipstick or other oil-based stains. Water that has soaked into microfiber fabric often causes a darkening of that area. Work the rubbing alcohol gently into that area.

steps.headline: Soak up excess liquid with white paper towels immediately after the stain was created.
Put a drop of hand dish washing soap, like Dawn, on a white cloth.
Pour 1 drop of water on the liquid to activate it.
Rub gently on the microfiber food stain until it is removed.
steps.description: This should work on oil-based food. Do not use this process on microfiber couches that indicate "S" on their care tag. This means no water-based solvents should be used.

steps.headline: Sprinkle baking soda on the stain.
Let it sit for 5 minutes to soak up any liquid.
Vacuum up the soiled baking soda.
Reapply baking soda if the spill or smell remains.
steps.description: This method should work for urine stains. Use a solvent in addition if the stain is not completely removed.

steps.headline: Wrap ice cubes in a plastic bag.
Apply the cold bag to the gum until it hardens.
Tug at the gum from the corners.
steps.description: Try to pull it off in 1 piece.

steps.headline: Reapply the ice if the gum is not fully hardened.

text: Ink Stain Removal Pour a small amount of rubbing alcohol on a white towel.  Rub the stain gently with the towel. Be sure to contain the alcohol to only the stained portion of the couch. Wipe it clean of any excess alcohol.  Repeat 2 to 3 times until the stain is removed. This method also works to remove water rings, lipstick or other oil-based stains. Water that has soaked into microfiber fabric often causes a darkening of that area. Work the rubbing alcohol gently into that area. Food Stain Removal Soak up excess liquid with white paper towels immediately after the stain was created.  Put a drop of hand dish washing soap, like Dawn, on a white cloth.  Pour 1 drop of water on the liquid to activate it.  Rub gently on the microfiber food stain until it is removed. This should work on oil-based food. Do not use this process on microfiber couches that indicate "S" on their care tag. This means no water-based solvents should be used. Smell Removal Sprinkle baking soda on the stain.  Let it sit for 5 minutes to soak up any liquid.  Vacuum up the soiled baking soda.  Reapply baking soda if the spill or smell remains. This method should work for urine stains. Use a solvent in addition if the stain is not completely removed. Gum Removal Wrap ice cubes in a plastic bag.  Apply the cold bag to the gum until it hardens.  Tug at the gum from the corners. Try to pull it off in 1 piece. Reapply the ice if the gum is not fully hardened.  Finished.
sentences: Ink Stain Removal Pour a small amount of rubbing alcohol on a white towel.
Rub the stain gently with the towel.
Be sure to contain the alcohol to only the stained portion of the couch.
Wipe it clean of any excess alcohol.
Repeat 2 to 3 times until the stain is removed.
This method also works to remove water rings, lipstick or other oil-based stains.
Water that has soaked into microfiber fabric often causes a darkening of that area.
Work the rubbing alcohol gently into that area.
Food Stain Removal Soak up excess liquid with white paper towels immediately after the stain was created.
Put a drop of hand dish washing soap, like Dawn, on a white cloth.
Pour 1 drop of water on the liquid to activate it.
Rub gently on the microfiber food stain until it is removed.
This should work on oil-based food.
Do not use this process on microfiber couches that indicate "S" on their care tag.
This means no water-based solvents should be used.
Smell Removal Sprinkle baking soda on the stain.
Let it sit for 5 minutes to soak up any liquid.
Vacuum up the soiled baking soda.
Reapply baking soda if the spill or smell remains.
This method should work for urine stains.
Use a solvent in addition if the stain is not completely removed.
Gum Removal Wrap ice cubes in a plastic bag.
Apply the cold bag to the gum until it hardens.
Tug at the gum from the corners.
Try to pull it off in 1 piece.
Reapply the ice if the gum is not fully hardened.
Finished.
